det.name: Vallarai/Centella asiatica
det.soil: Plant naturally grows over moist, fertile, loose, sandy loam and clayey soil.
det.growth:
Get a bunch of vallarai from the market. You will definitely find at least a few with a little root (even a little root works). Keep aside 3-4 plants with root.

Once the pot is ready, plant the vallarai with root 4-5 cm deep and pack the soil around it well.

Place the pot in a place that receives morning sunlight or partial afternoon sunlight. That’s it.

Sprinkle water until the root takes hold and the plant settles. Once the plant settles, you can water the plant, if the soil is dry. Make sure the soil is damp and not soggy. So avoid over watering the plants.
det.water: Water it sufficiently during hot weather and provide drainage facility during rainy seasons.
det.sunlight: The plants grow well under shade and can tolerate heavy shade.

det.name: Brahmi / Bacopa monnieri
det.water: Water them well. Bacopa grows well in wet condition.
det.sunlight: Bacopa favors partial shade although it will survive in full sun.
det.soil: The plant grows well in poorly drained soils. Near-neutral, clayey loam to clayey soils are best suited for the growth of Bacopa monnieri.
det.growth:
The cuttings of about 5-6 m long form the parent plant, each with a few leaves and nodes are ideal and establish easily. The cuttings are transplanted in wet soil at spacing of 10 x 10 cm to get maximum herbage yield.
 It is very essential to water the plant after transplanting for the survival and establishment of the plants. Irrigation should be avoided during rainy season. Brahmi likes to grow in a warm position. It will tolerate full sun and grows well in part sun.

det.name: Tulsi
det.water: Water your tulsi when the top layer of soil becomes dry.
det.sunlight: 6-8 hours of sunlight per day.  It can survive part sunlight conditions, with as little as 4 hours of direct sunlight per day.
det.soil: Sandy loam soil with good organic matter is considered ideal.

det.name: Pyrethrum / Daisy
det.water: Daisies don’t require a set watering schedule; in fact, they prefer the soil to dry out somewhat between watering. Daisies don’t need watering in the winter unless the weather is unseasonably dry.
det.sunlight: Daisies need as much sunlight as possible, especially in cooler climates. Most species requireat least 6 hours of direct sunlight a day during the summer to live.
det.soil: A well-drained loamy soil and a sunny position suit pyrethrums best. though they will grow well on chalky soils.

det.name: Digitalis / Foxglove
det.water: Foxglove enjoys moist but not constantly soaked soil. It requires supplemental water during dry periods in the summer. If the plant gets too much water and remains soaked for long periods of time can result, killing the plant before it flowers.
det.sunlight: Most foxgloves thrive in light shade. D. purpurea loves to be cool, but Mediterranean species need sun.
det.soil: Foxglove plants grow best in rich, well draining soil. Caring for foxglove plants will include keeping the soil moist. As a biennial or short lived perennial, the gardener can encourage re-growth of foxglove flowers by not allowing the soil to dry out or to get too soggy.

det.name: Aswagandha
det.water: Watering should be economical and only when plant seems thirsty. Indian ginseng is a drought resistant herb and doesn’t like wet feet.
det.sunlight: Choose a wind-sheltered planting site that receives plenty of direct sunlight.
det.soil: The soil should be loose, deep and well-drained. Ashwagandha grows well in sandy loam or light red soils . Black or heavy soils having good drainage are also suitable for ashwagandha cultivation.
det.growth:
Plant ashwagandha in dry and sunny location of your garden.

 Plant seeds 2 cm deep and 10 cm apart when temperature is around 70 F (20 C). Seeds will germinate in two weeks. Water the seedlings well while they are establishing. Thin out the weak plants after a month of growing, leaving the space around 50 – 60 cm between plants. Watering should be economical and only when plant seems thirsty.

det.name: Medicinal Disoscorea
det.water: Water the plant around the edges of the pot and not directly on the tuber. Allow the soil to become nearly dry before watering again
det.sunlight: Grows well in partially shaded bed with freely draining soil.
det.soil: Sandy loam soil is most suitable for its cultivation and better yield of corm.

det.name: Medicinal Solanum
det.water: It is a drought-adapted species. Water once in two days and increase the watering if the weather is too hot. Plan to water solanum regularly for good flowering.
det.sunlight: Grows best in full sun or part shade.
det.soil: Well drained loamy soils are suitable.  Being a hardy plant, even land with medium fertility can give a good stand.

det.name: Vinca / Periwinkle
det.water: Water the potting mixture plentifully, but do not allow the pot to stand in water.
det.sunlight: Bright light, included three or four hours of direct sunlight daily, is essential for good flowering.
det.soil: Plant are best grown as annual bedding plants in well-drained sandy loams. Water logged soils are not preffered.

det.name: Aloe
det.water: Water only after the soil seems dry
det.sunlight: 8-10 hrs a day
det.soil: Aloe genus require sandy or gravelly soil with very good drainage to reduce the risk of root rot and nutritional deficiencies. When planted in containers, aloe vera plants do well in a mixture of extra sand, granite grit or perlite added. When planting aloe vera outdoors, look for a sandy spot that dries out completely after rainfall or on a slope.

det.name: Stevia
det.water: Do not let your stevia's soil dry out completely, but standing water, or wet soil should be avoided, as it will encourage the roots to rot. Once established, Stevia is a low water, low maintenance plant.
det.sunlight: Stevia thrives in full sun but during hot summer, arrange light shade during the afternoon.
det.soil: Stevia plants do best in a rich, loamy soil .It is a good idea to add compost for extra nutrients if the soil in your area is sandy. Frequent light watering is recommended during the summer months. Adding a layer of compost around each stevia plant will help keep the shallow feeder roots from drying out.

det.name: Medicinal Coleus
det.water: Maintain a moist soil. Water stagnation should be avoided. During summer water twice a day. Water the soil directly, since wet leaves are vulnerable to disease.
det.sunlight: It varies for a different types. Check the table in the following link:
det.soil: Well drained red loamy soils are suited for cultivation. Water stagnation should be avoided.

det.name: Gloriosa / Kalihari
det.water: Grows well in good water and moisture condition.
det.sunlight: 6-8 hrs of sunlight. Some protection from afternoon sun may be needed as well.
det.soil: It is found growing successfully in red or black loamy soils with medium water holding capacity and good drainage.

det.name: Cut Rose
det.soil: Roses also thrive when planted in well-drained soil that is rich in organic matter. In heavy clay soil, mix in compost, peat moss, and other organic matter to improve drainage.
det.water: During hot, dry season, even more may be needed depending on the size of the bushes. In spite of their need for abundance of water, roses hate standing in water and provision for proper drainage is essential.
det.sunlight: Plant roses where they will receive a minimum of 5 to 6 hours of full sun per day. Morning sun is especially important because it dries the leaves, which helps prevent diseases. Growing roses in partial sun  weaken gradually.

det.name: Cut Chrysanthemum
det.soil: Well drained sandy loam soil with good texture and aeration or growing medium made of 1: 1: 2 of soil, compost and cocopeat.
det.water: Allow the growing media to cycle from moist to slightly dry. Avoid both excess dry downs and long periods of wet media, especially in poor weather conditions, as this increases potential for root disease.
det.sunlight: 6-8 hours of sunlight per day. Choose a spot in your yard that gets sunny — a little bit of shade is okay. Chrysanthemums like the morning sun.

det.name: Carnation
det.soil: Carnations thrive in fertile, well- drained, slightly alkaline (pH 6.75) soil.
det.water: Carnations do not require much water, except in the hot months. You must be careful not to make the soil too wet which can produce yellow foliage.
det.sunlight: Carnations need full sunlight, about 4-6 hours everyday.

det.name: Orchids
det.soil: Its soil should be aerated and well drained.  They can be happy growing in peat moss, fir bark, dried fern roots, sphagnum moss, rock wool, perlite, cork nuggets, stones, coconut fiber, lava rock or a blend that combines several of these materials.
det.water: It's easier to kill an orchid by watering it too frequently than by not watering enough. Water your orchid about once per week and allow it to dry out between watering.
det.sunlight: Many orchids enjoy indirect sunlight: direct sunlight cases them to burn, while not enough creates a plant that doesn't flower.

det.name: Lilium
det.soil: Well drained sterile medium is required. Water trapped beneath the overlapping scales on the lily bulb may cause rot, so a well-drained site is essential.
det.water: Lilies generally don't need a lot of water, so only water if required. One tip is to wait for the plant to drop slightly before watering.
det.sunlight: 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight a day. If it’s too shady, the stems will attempt to lean towards the sun or get spindly and fall over.

det.name: Gladiolus
det.soil: Gladiolus like well-drained, sandy loam soil. The corms will rot if the soil is too heavy and wet. If you have clay soil, grow in raised beds and loosen the soil to 12 inches deep before planting.
det.water: Keep gladiolus plants well watered with at least 1 inch of water a week. This amount may have to increase during periods of drought or if you're growing in raised beds.
det.sunlight: Gladiolus grow and flower best in full sun. Gladiolus corms will flower in part shade, but the colors will not be as vivid as when planted in full sun, and the plant won't grow quite as well.

det.name: Pyrethrum / Daisy
det.soil: A well-drained loamy soil and a sunny position suit pyrethrums best. though they will grow well on chalky soils.
det.water: Daisies don’t require a set watering schedule; in fact, they prefer the soil to dry out somewhat between watering. Daisies don’t need watering in the winter unless the weather is unseasonably dry.
det.sunlight: Daisies need as much sunlight as possible, especially in cooler climates. Most species requireat least 6 hours of direct sunlight a day during the summer to live.

det.name: Nerium / Oleander
det.soil: Almost any soil type will do, including heavy clay, well-drained sand, marshy plots but for best results use red lateritic or black or loamy soils with adequate drainage.
det.water: It is a fallacy that you do not need to be watering your oleander plants. Water it only if the plant seems to drop. Once it has been watered it would bounce back.
det.sunlight: Oleander loves full sun but it also survives in partial shade, but the less sun, the fewer flowers. It will not grow at all in full shade.

det.name: Jasminum sambac / Malligai
det.soil: Jasmine can be grown on a wide range of soils. Well drained loamy or red loamy fertile soil is ideal for their condition.
det.water: Jasmine plants need a lot of water, especially when they are in bloom. It is best to always keep the soil slightly moist.
det.sunlight: All jasmines prefer full sun to partial shade. The ideal planting position should be warm, sunny and sheltered.

det.name: Pomegranate
det.soil: Deep loamy or alluvial, well drain soil is highly recommended for pomegranate cultivation.
det.water: Water it well during the initial stage and flowering stage. Let the soil dry between watering.  It can withstand drought.
det.sunlight: Pomegranates require full sun to grow and thrive. You should plant the tree in the sunniest and warmest place of your yard if possible.

det.name: Papaya
det.soil: Papaya can grow on a variety of soils, yet the best soil is deep, rich, alluvial soils. Soil should have good drainage and be properly prepared before planting.
det.water: Papayas need plenty of water to grow tasty fruit, but the plants do not tolerate wet feet. To avoid overwatering the papaya, water deeply only when the top 1 inch of soil dries.
det.sunlight: Grow best in full sun. Papayas love the heat and sunlight.

det.name: Banana
det.soil: Bananas will grow in most soils, but to thrive, they should be planted in a rich, well-drained soil. The best possible location would be above an abandoned compost heap. The banana is not tolerant of salty soils.
det.water: Bananas have a high water demand and 25mm/week is regarded as the minimum for satisfactory growth.
det.sunlight: Outdoor banana plants require plenty of sunlight. Indoor banana trees require bright light for about 12 hours.

det.name: Pears
det.soil: A well drained sandy loam is best, although pear trees can grow in heavier soils, especially in warm climates. If your soil is heavy clay, consider amending it with compost and moistened peat moss.
det.water: Average young pear tree needs a lot of water in order to develop strong roots, leaves and finally fruits. Pears are delicate, however, and too much or too little watering can lead to yellowing or dropped leaves and subpar fruit.
det.sunlight: Pears require full sun. Be sure to choose a spot that will ensure at least six to eight hours of sun, not only for your sapling but for your full grown pear.

det.name: Pineapple
det.soil: Pineapples grown indoors need a potting mix of light, sandy loam as well. Because drainage is essential for pineapple growth, the right container is also important. Clay containers are a good choice for growing pineapples.
det.water: You need only wet the soil once a week, and when the plant is indoors, it is best to apply all the water to the soil.
det.sunlight: It require full, all-day sunlight to produce the best growth and to eventually fruit. A lack of sunlight can slow foliage development and prevent flowering.

det.name: Onions
det.soil: Onions will grow in almost any soil from sandy loams to heavy clay. The soil should be firm. If your soil is heavy then you can introduce some organic compost or manure into the soil to help its moisture retaining properties.
det.water: Onions do need a lot of water, but the soil shouldn't be soggy all the time. Just enough water is better than too much. It’s best to water early in the morning.
det.sunlight: Onions prefer full sun and will survive if planted in partial shade, but the onions will be smaller and the plant will be more susceptible to pests and disease. Onions are unable to grow in full shade.

det.name: Bottle Gourd
det.soil: Bottle gourd tolerates a wide range of soil but prefers a well drained sandy loam soil that is rich in organic matter.
det.water: If it feels dry, its time to water. A healthy Bottle Gourd plant needs water in a uniform manner, so that the soil does not dry up. Proper watering in the growing season encourages plant flower and fruit.
det.sunlight: Bottle Gourd plants love the sun, so plant it in an area with good sunshine for good produce.

det.name: Brinjal / Egg plant
det.soil: The eggplant requires moisture equal to about one inch of rain a week and good drainage is essential. Eggplant does not like weeds, so weed around them carefully. It is generally conceded that warm, sandy soils are best adapted for eggplant.
det.water: Eggplants are best watered approximately 1 inch per week during the growing season. Ensure that the soil dries in between watering. Increase the watering during hot weathers.
det.sunlight: Growing eggplants outdoors requires full sun. Ample sunlight provides the energy needed for large fruit production through photosynthesis.

det.name: Chilies
det.soil: Chillies love light loamy soil. A little bit of silt, lots of rich organic matter with lots of nice air pockets and good drainage.
det.water: Chilli plants enjoy a good watering followed by a period without water – until the compost is almost dry. Select a compost with good drainage to help keep air in the soil and try to avoid the pot standing in water.
det.sunlight: 6 hours of sunlight a day is the minimum amount of light needed for them to grow, though more sunlight is better.

det.name: Tomatos
det.soil: Loam and sandy loam soils are best for tomato production, but these plants will grow in almost all soil types except heavy clay.
det.water: Water newly planted tomatoes well to make sure soil is moist and ideal for growing. Early in the growing season, watering plants daily in the morning. As temperatures increase, you might need to water tomato plants twice a day.
det.sunlight: Tomatoes thrive in full sun. For healthy growth, tomato plants require at least 8 hours of direct sunlight a day.

det.name: Curry leaf
det.soil: Red sandy loam soils with good drainage are ideal for better leaf yield.
det.water: Water the plant if its upper layer is dry. Do not water log it as it may weaken the plant.
det.sunlight: The plant grows well in full to part sun,

det.name: Capsicum
det.soil: Well-drained sandy loam soils having good percolation is most suitable to grow capsicum.
det.water: Water moderately when the op soil seems dry.
det.sunlight: Capsicum grows well in partial sun to shade – around 3-4 hours of morning/evening sunlight with some afternoon shade.

det.name: Rosemary
det.soil: The soil needs to be fast draining and light loamy soil. Do not add fertilizer to the soil. In a pot, succulent & cactus mix would be fine as well as potting soil; the latter you'd need to water less often.
det.water: Rosemary has just two requirements: don't let the soil become waterlogged or dry out completely.
det.sunlight: Rosemary should receive at least 6 hours of sun each day; it grows best in full sun.

det.name: Lemongrass
det.soil: Give this herb rich, well-drained soil. Amend planting holes with composted manure to improve fertility and enhance the soil’s ability to hold water.
det.water: The best time to water any plant is early morning or late afternoon. These plants should never be allowed to dry out completely.
det.sunlight: Lemongrass grows in full sun, even in hot climates. At least six hours of direct sun per day will meet the plants' energy needs. Plants growing in shade will be sparse and may attract pests.

det.name: Geranium
det.soil: A deep light porous well drained soil rich in organic matter is suitable for Geranium.
det.water: Allow the soil get dry in between each watering. If the soil is dry all the way through the top inch, provide the flowers with enough water to dampen the soil without soaking it.
det.sunlight: Geraniums require six to eight hours of direct sunlight to thrive, but some varieties prefer a bit of shade in the afternoon.

det.name: Patchouli
det.soil: It requires deep, well-drained, fertile, slightly acidic, deep loamy soil, rich in humus and nutrients. It flourishes best in loose deep loamy soils, rich in organic matter which makes a loose friable texture.
det.water: Patchouli prefers regular irrigation but not soggy, waterlogged soil. Water the plant once every week that the plant receives no natural rainfall, providing enough water to soak the soil to a depth of about 8 inches.
det.sunlight: The plant thrives in full sunlight but tolerates partial shade.

det.name: Mint
det.soil: Well drained loamy soil high in organic matter content is suitable.
det.water: Mint needs a lot of water. Keep the soil damp, but don't soak it. If your mint is in direct sun, water it more frequently.
det.sunlight: Mint performs its best in full sun, as long as the soil is kept moist, but it also thrives in partial shade.

profile.title: sunt aut facere repellat provident occaecati excepturi optio reprehenderit
profile.body:
quia et suscipit
suscipit recusandae consequuntur expedita et cum
reprehenderit molestiae ut ut quas totam
nostrum rerum est autem sunt rem eveniet architecto
